content.description: Language Disorder is a neurodevelopmental disorder characterized by persistent difficulties in the acquisition and use of language across modalities (spoken, written, sign) due to deficits in comprehension and/or production. Areas affected often include vocabulary, sentence structure/grammar, and discourse. Difficulties are substantially below age expectations, begin in the early developmental period, and result in functional impairment. Deficits are not attributable to hearing loss, motor speech disorder, intellectual disability, neurological or medical conditions, or lack of exposure.
content.diagnostic_criteria: A. Persistent difficulties in language acquisition and use across modalities due to deficits in comprehension or production (e.g., reduced vocabulary, limited sentence structure, impairments in discourse). B. Language abilities substantially below those expected for age, resulting in functional limitations. C. Onset in the early developmental period. D. Not attributable to hearing or other sensory impairment, motor dysfunction, neurological conditions, intellectual disability, global developmental delay, or lack of language exposure.

evaluation.clinical_interview: Developmental history, early milestones, language exposure(s), family history of speech/language disorders, functional impact at home/school.
speech_language_pathology: Standardized testing by SLP (e.g., CELF-5/CELF-Preschool-3, PLS-5, OWLS-II, TOLD, PPVT-5/EVT-3).
Language sample analysis (MLU, grammar errors, narrative/discourse), pragmatic screening, and speech sound screening.
evaluation.audiology_hearing: Hearing screening or full audiologic evaluation to rule out hearing loss.
evaluation.cognitive_academic: Screen cognitive abilities and academic skills (reading/writing) to identify co-occurring learning disorders.
evaluation.medical_neuro: Oral-motor exam; consider neurological evaluation if regression, seizures, or focal findings.
evaluation.rule_outs: Differentiate from Social (Pragmatic) Communication Disorder, Autism Spectrum Disorder, speech sound disorder, intellectual disability, selective mutism, and insufficient language exposure.
evaluation.collateral_information: Teacher reports, school records/IEP, caregiver questionnaires; consider bilingual assessment with trained bilingual SLP or interpreter.
evaluation.cultural_linguistic_considerations: Assess in all languages the child uses; compare to peers with similar cultural/linguistic backgrounds.

content.prevalence: Estimated ~7â€“8% of young children; more common in males. Rates vary with assessment tools and language exposure.
content.age_of_onset: Symptoms emerge in early childhood as language should be developing (typically noticed by preschool/early school years).
content.prognosis: Many improve with early, intensive, language-focused intervention; persistent deficits may remain in complex language and literacy. Early identification, family engagement, and school supports predict better academic and social outcomes.

expressive: Errors with verb tenses, plurals, or pronouns
Difficulty telling coherent stories or describing events
receptive: Difficulty understanding questions, directions, or classroom language
Poor comprehension of complex sentences or figurative language
Needs repetition, visuals, or simplified language to follow
discourse_narrative: Difficulty maintaining topics and using cohesive devices

severity_levels.mild: Language difficulties cause some challenges but respond to accommodations/intervention; minimal functional impact.
severity_levels.moderate: Marked language limitations across settings with notable academic and social impact.
severity_levels.severe: Pervasive language impairment with significant functional limitations; requires intensive, ongoing supports.

psychological: Executive function weaknesses (working memory, processing speed) contributing to language learning difficulty
environmental: Limited access to early language stimulation (not causal but can compound difficulties)

impact_on_life.academic: Reading comprehension, written expression, and content learning are affected; difficulty following directions and participating in class.
impact_on_life.social: Challenges making/maintaining friendships due to conversational or narrative difficulties.
impact_on_life.emotional: Frustration, reduced confidence, risk of anxiety or demoralization related to communication demands.

speech_language_therapy: Direct SLP intervention targeting vocabulary, grammar/morphosyntax, sentence formulation, and discourse/narratives.
Explicit instruction with high-repetition practice; visual supports; recasting/expansion techniques.
parent_implemented_interventions: Caregiver coaching (e.g., focused stimulation, dialogic reading, modeling and expansion in daily routines).
school_accommodations: IEP/504 supports: simplified/visual directions, pre-teaching vocabulary, extended time, alternative response formats, small-group instruction.
Collaborative goals across SLP, classroom, and resource specialists.
literacy_supports: Early and explicit phonological awareness and language-to-literacy instruction; structured reading/writing interventions.
assistive_technology: Visual organizers, text-to-speech/speech-to-text; AAC for severe expressive deficits if indicated.

treatment_goals: Improve comprehension and expression across academic and daily contexts
Build vocabulary, grammar, and discourse/narrative skills
Support literacy development and classroom participation
Increase communicative confidence and reduce frustration
missed_diagnosis_factors: Attributing difficulties to shyness, behavior, or inattention without language assessment
Assuming bilingualism is the cause rather than testing in both languages
Overlooking receptive deficits when expressive speech sounds adequate
Relying solely on brief screeners without standardized SLP evaluation
overdiagnosis_factors: Pathologizing typical second-language acquisition patterns or dialectal differences
Labeling transient developmental language variability as disorder
Diagnosing based on low vocabulary exposure without considering opportunity to learn
Confusing pragmatic-only difficulties with Language Disorder (may be SPCD)

coding.note: ICD-10-CM commonly uses F80.2 (Mixed receptive-expressive). If primarily expressive with intact comprehension, some payers use F80.1.

warning_signs: Few words or short phrases beyond expected age
Difficulty following simple directions for age
Persistent grammar errors and limited sentence length
Struggles with narratives and classroom language demands
self_help_strategies: Daily shared reading with dialogic prompts and vocabulary modeling
Use visual schedules, picture cues, and graphic organizers
Chunk directions; ask for repetition/clarification; pre-learn key vocabulary
Practice storytelling about daily events with who/what/where/when/why prompts
real_life_examples: A 6-year-old with short, grammatically simple sentences receives SLP services; with visuals and targeted grammar practice, classroom participation improves.
A 9-year-old struggles to understand multi-step directions; accommodations and language-to-literacy interventions raise reading comprehension.
content.when_to_seek_help: Seek SLP evaluation if language delays or difficulties persist beyond expected developmental windows, interfere with learning or social participation, or if there is concern from caregivers/teachers.

positive_factors: Early identification and intensive SLP intervention
Strong caregiver engagement and language-rich environment
Coordinated school supports and targeted literacy instruction
challenging_factors: Late treatment initiation or inconsistent services
Significant receptive deficits or broader cognitive weaknesses
